name: ISO 8601 date standard
description: a scheme for representing a date string in a Year-Month-DayTHour:Minute:Second.microsecond format

definition: a cyberattack where an attacker inserts malicious code into an application by exploiting a vulnerability in how the application handles user input, then the code is executed as part of a command or query, potentially leading to unauthorized actions like data theft, system compromise, or denial of service

name: YAML
definition: a human-readable data serialization language
said of an operation that changes an object instead of producing a modified copy
instances: appending an elemnt to a list

name: initial
description: set a CSS property to its default value

name: inherit
description: specifies that a property should inherit its value from its parent element

examples.description: set the text-color for <span> elements to blue, except those inside elements with class="extra"

name: display
description: specifies the display behavior (the type of rendering box) of an element

instances.name: inline
instances.description: displays an element as an inline element (like <span>); any height and width properties will have no effect

instances.name: block
instances.description:
displays an element as a block element (like

): it starts on a new line, and takes up the whole width

instances.name: contents
instances.description: makes the container disappear, making the child elements children of the element the next level up in the DOM

instances.name: flex
instances.description: displays an element as a block-level flex container

instances.name: grid
instances.description: displays an element as a block-level grid container

instances.name: inline-block
instances.description: displays an element as an inline-level block container. The element itself is formatted as an inline element, but you can apply height and width values

instances.name: inline-flex
instances.description: displays an element as an inline-level flex container

instances.name: inline-grid
instances.description: displays an element as an inline-level grid container

instances.name: inline-table
instances.description: the element is displayed as an inline-level table

instances.name: list-item
instances.description: let the element behave like a <li> element

instances.name: run-in
instances.description: displays an element as either block or inline, depending on context

instances.name: table
instances.description: let the element behave like a <table> element

instances.name: table-caption
instances.description: let the element behave like a <caption> element

instances.name: table-column-group
instances.description: let the element behave like a <colgroup> element

instances.name: table-header-group
instances.description: let the element behave like a <thead> element

instances.name: table-footer-group
instances.description: let the element behave like a <tfoot> element

instances.name: table-row-group
instances.description: let the element behave like a <tbody> element

instances.name: table-cell
instances.description: let the element behave like a <td> element

instances.name: table-column
instances.description: let the element behave like a <col> element

instances.name: table-row
instances.description: let the element behave like a <tr> element

instances.name: none
instances.description: the element is completely removed

instances.name: initial
instances.description: sets this property to its default value

instances.name: inherit
instances.description: inherits this property from its parent element

name: inline-block
description: combines the features of both inline and block elements
will appear on the same line as other inline or inline-block elements
you can set the width, height, margin-top, and margin-bottom properties for the element (like block elements)

name: base
action: specify a default URL and/or a default target for all links on a page through a "href" and/or "target" attribute
notes: there can only be one single <base> element in a document
the <base> element must be inside the <head> element
target values are one of _blank, _parent, _self, and _top

name: contentEditable
action: sets or returns if the content of an element is editable

examples.comment: sets the content of 'myP' to be editable
set paragraph to contenteditable, wait for the user to write something else, then press button to read it

definition: the process of generalizing concrete details, such as attributes, away from the study of objects and systems to focus attention on details of greater importance
instances: the usage of abstract data types to separate usage from working representations of data within programs
the concept of functions or subroutines which represent a specific way of implementing control flow
the process of reorganizing common behavior from groups of non-abstract classes into abstract classes using inheritance and sub-classes, as seen in object-oriented programming languages

name: Wayback Machine
definition: un servicio y una base de datos que contiene copias de una enorme cantidad de páginas o sitios de Internet. Como consecuencia de este proyecto, también se puede consultar la historia y las modificaciones de las páginas a través del tiempo

a visual design technique where a website's foreground images move at a different speed or direction than the background. Scrolling reveals subtle depth changes, drawing attention to images and text as you move down the page
a basic unit of information that represents a letter, number, punctuation, space, symbol, or control code; it can be a single alphanumeric character like "A" or a special character like "$" or "& "
a number assigned to represent an abstract character in a system for representing text (such as Unicode)
notes: In Unicode, a code point is expressed in the form "U+1234" where "1234" is the assigned number. For example, the character "A" is assigned a code point of U+0041

Character encoding forms, such as UTF-8 and UTF-16, determine how a Unicode code point should be encoded as a sequence of bytes. Different encoding forms may encode the same code point as different byte sequences: for example, the Cyrillic character "Ф", whose code point is U+0424, is encoded as 0xd0a4 in UTF-8 and as 0x0424 in UTF-16.

definition: a run of characters
notes: strings are usually delimeted by double quotes, less often by single quotes (standard SQL), back ticks etc.

definition: a name pattern becoming expanded into a list of names matching that pattern
a character that invokes an alternative interpretation on the following characters in a character sequence
functions: to encode a syntactic entity, such as device commands or special data, which cannot be directly represented by the alphabet

to represent characters, referred to as "character quoting", which cannot be typed in the current context, or would have an undesired interpretation; in this case, an escape sequence is a digraph consisting of an escape character itself and a "quoted" character
notes: In the telecommunications field, escape characters are used to indicate that the following characters are encoded differently. This is used to alter control characters that would otherwise be noticed and acted on by the underlying telecommunications hardware, such as illegal characters. In this context, the use of escape characters is often referred to as quoting.

definition: a collection of software that manages a computer's hardware and applications by allocating resources, including memory, CPU, input/output devices and file storage

functions.name: enabling users to communicate with computers through a user-friendly interface
processor management
functions.definition: allocating various tasks to a processor and giving it enough time to function

functions.name: memory management
functions.definition: allocating and deallocating memory across different processes

functions.name: device management
functions.definition: controlling the workings of input-output devices, including receiving and communicating requests, performing tasks and interacting with peripheral devices such as printers and cameras

functions.name: file management
functions.definition: tracking information that supports file system storage and maintaining integrity of data

functions.name: security
functions.definition: ensuring the confidentiality and integrity of data, including protecting against unauthorised or malicious access and relaying vulnerabilities

functions.name: error detection
functions.definition: checking for external threats, malicious software and hardware changes

functions.name: job scheduling
functions.definition: determining which applications need to run in which order

instances.name: Microsoft Windows
notes: the most widely used global operating system, the market leader of desktop OS since the early 1990s

instances.name: iOS
notes: the second most widely used mobile OS
iOS was developed solely for use with Apple hardware devices such as the iPhone, iPad, iPod and other handheld devices

instances.name: ChromeOS
notes: developed for use with tablets and netbooks
an intuitive, secure and straightforward OS

definition: to overwrite or destroy data in a resource, such as a file, memory location, or processor register, often unintentionally
a flag used to indicate whether a block of memory or data has been modified since it was last written to a slower storage medium (like disk)
escaping that neither honoured nor disrupts parsing
the process of clearing out or cleaning data from a buffer or cache
software with, often unwanted, adverts
decentralised mining network and software development platform rolled into one
a cryptographic transaction ledger
the collection of all methods in artificial intelligence research that are based on high-level symbolic (human-readable) representations of problems, logic and search
notes: The Symbolic AI paradigm led to seminal ideas in search, symbolic programming languages, agents, multi-agent systems, the semantic web, and the strengths and limitations of formal knowledge and reasoning systems
history: Symbolic AI was the dominant paradigm of AI research from the mid-1950s until the mid-1990s. Researchers in the 1960s and the 1970s were convinced that symbolic approaches would eventually succeed in creating a machine with artificial general intelligence and considered this the ultimate goal of their field.[citation needed] An early boom, with early successes such as the Logic Theorist and Samuel's Checkers Playing Program, led to unrealistic expectations and promises and was followed by the first AI Winter as funding dried up. A second boom (1969–1986) occurred with the rise of expert systems, their promise of capturing corporate expertise, and an enthusiastic corporate embrace. That boom, and some early successes, e.g., with XCON at DEC, was followed again by later disappointment. Problems with difficulties in knowledge acquisition, maintaining large knowledge bases, and brittleness in handling out-of-domain problems arose. Another, second, AI Winter (1988–2011) followed. Subsequently, AI researchers focused on addressing underlying problems in handling uncertainty and in knowledge acquisition. Uncertainty was addressed with formal methods such as hidden Markov models, Bayesian reasoning, and statistical relational learning. Symbolic machine learning addressed the knowledge acquisition problem with contributions including Version Space, Valiant's PAC learning, Quinlan's ID3 decision-tree learning, case-based learning, and inductive logic programming to learn relations.

Neural networks, a subsymbolic approach, had been pursued from early days and reemerged strongly in 2012. Early examples are Rosenblatt's perceptron learning work, the backpropagation work of Rumelhart, Hinton and Williams, and work in convolutional neural networks by LeCun et al. in 1989. However, neural networks were not viewed as successful until about 2012: "Until Big Data became commonplace, the general consensus in the Al community was that the so-called neural-network approach was hopeless. Systems just didn't work that well, compared to other methods. ... A revolution came in 2012, when a number of people, including a team of researchers working with Hinton, worked out a way to use the power of GPUs to enormously increase the power of neural networks." Over the next several years, deep learning had spectacular success in handling vision, speech recognition, speech synthesis, image generation, and machine translation. However, since 2020, as inherent difficulties with bias, explanation, comprehensibility, and robustness became more apparent with deep learning approaches; an increasing number of AI researchers have called for combining the best of both the symbolic and neural network approaches and addressing areas that both approaches have difficulty with, such as common-sense reasoning.
